newsitem.title: USA: Netscape raises corporate software prices.
newsitem.headline: Netscape raises corporate software prices.

text.p: Web browser power Netscape Communications Corp. plans to raise prices for much of its software for corporate intranets, the internal computer networks that mimic the Internet, a company executive said Wednesday.
Mountain View, Calif.-based Netscape is battling bigger rival Microsoft Corp. and the Lotus unit of International Business Machines Corp. for a piece of the intranet software market.

Netscape will announce higher prices for its software for personal computers and servers, the computers that run networks, Eric Hahn, the company's vice president of engineering, said in response to a question at the Goldman Sachs Technology Symposium.
The price of Communicator, Netscape's integrated communications package designed to run on individual PCs, will rise to $59 from $49, Hahn said.
The company's enterprise server software will be priced at $1,295, up from $995.
Prices of several other Netscape software products will be boosted by similar margins. Details were not immediately available.
"We remain less expensive on the acquisition costs (than rival products)," Hahn said.
If a customer's cost of deploying and installing Netscape software is figured in, the software is an even better deal than rival products offered by Microsoft Corp. and Lotus, he said.
